Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story: I sat at my cubicle, headset pressing into my ear, eyes flicking between the call list and the clock. My break was scheduled in ten minutes, but just then, Maya from the new hires pinged me: “Can I ask you something quick about the sales script?” As her mentor, I knew she relied on me for guidance, especially with her confidence still shaky. I wanted to help—giving advice, even casually, was part of why I liked mentoring. But the telemarketer in me felt the pressure of the compliance system, always watching. If I took even a minute off the phones outside my scheduled break, the system would flag me, and I’d have to explain myself to my supervisor again. My finger hovered over the “pause” button, heart thumping. I could see Maya’s message blinking, waiting for reassurance, but the clock kept ticking, and the threat of another warning loomed. I felt torn, caught between being the mentor Maya needed and the rule-abiding telemarketer my job demanded.
